hits.book_ref: CWWL, 1981, vol. 2, "The History and Revelation of the Lord's Recovery," ch. 7: The Recovery of Christ Being the Spirit
hits.snippet: In New Testament for English Readers Henry Alford’s explanatory note on 2 Corinthians 3:17 says, “The Lord of ver. 16, is the Spirit...which giveth life, ver. 6: meaning, ‘the Lord,’ as here spoken of, ‘Christ,’ ‘is the Spirit,’ is identical with the Holy Spirit...Christ, here, is the Spirit of Christ.” M. R. Vincent, in volume 3 of Word Studies in the New Testament, says, “The Lord Christ of ver. 16 is the Spirit who pervades and animates the new covenant.” Williston Walker says, “That all-transforming and indwelling Spirit is Christ Himself. ‘The Lord is the Spirit.’” Concerning 2 Corinthians 3:17, Lewis B. Smedes in All Things Made New says, “The Lord in verse 17 is the concrete individual Jesus who died and rose again and is now Lord of ‘all things.’ This identifiable and concrete person is the Spirit...the Spirit who is none other than Christ in His continuing actions on earth.” Hendrikus Berkhof, in his book The Doctrine of the Holy Spirit, also comments on verse 17: “The word ‘Lord’ in verses 17 and 18 always means Christ. He himself is the Spirit.”
